title: Intranuclear (G4C2)n RNA foci, transcribed from C9ORF72 hexanucleotide expansion mutation, form paraspeckle-like structures

author: Ana Bajc Česnik, Department of Biotechnology, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: OK, hi, first I'd like to thank the organizers for giving me this opportunity to talk here.
So I come from Boris Rogel app.
He is actually my Pi an I'd like to present the work that people in our lab did on.
Internuclear repeat RNA foci, transcribed from C9 or 72 hexa nucleotide expansion mutation forum, Paris beckerleg structures.
So.
First, I'd like to say something about the background, so actually see 9 or 72 mutation is the most common genetic cost for LS.
Actually, about 40% of familial LSV because of this mutation.

It is actually quite a long expected repeat sequence that it's in the first intron of the C9 or sent it to Jean normal healthy individual have between 2 and 19 repeats an alias patients have from 500 to more than 5000 repeats.
Because it's located in the intron, it is.
It's been suggested that the disease mechanism probably involves our name, and to illustrate how many different structures these RNA and DNA can take.
Here is a schematic, so it was proposed that there could be 3 possible mechanisms of C9 or 72 toxicity.
First haploinsufficiency, then repeat associated RNA toxicity.
And then also dipeptide repeat protein toxicity and.
This work we focused on repeat associated RNA toxicity.
So we wanted to determine which proteins could bind to.
This repeats and to accomplish this we first transcribed.
RNA in vitro.
And then we put it in the test tube and then we took cells from red, cortex and cerebellum.
We separated nuclear an cytoplasmic fractions and then we put those things together.
So RNA and proteins.
And then of course, specific proteins bound to RNA.
We eluded them and then we separated them on the ACIS page gel.
Those bands that didn't come up in the controls we exist out of the jail and then we analyze them with mass spectroscopy.
So and we found some interesting hits for H&R MPH.
It was already shown that it actually binds to those RNA foci, but we wanted to try for all of the other proteins if we can find some colocalization in the cell culture.
So.
We performed this experiment.
We took heck cells.
We transfected down with the repeats, incubated them for 24 hours, then fix them, and then we performed fish to probe for the foci.
An immuno fluorescence for the target proteins, an of all of the test that proteins only as of Q actually colocalized with the full side.
At this point I'd like to say something about as of Q so SFP Q is found in power speckles.
Doctor Let already introduced the power speckles.
In his lecture.
But I'd like to.
Remind you about them, so dare specific 4 million cells.
They are located in the nucleus.
There are actually assembled on the backbone of the long non coding RNA.
Need one, so that's the yellow thing here.
And it is thought in the field that need one is actually necessary for the assembly of Dipper speckles an their proposed function.
Is this orchestration of the RNA binding proteins an also nuclear retention of M RNA's?
In the last two years, they identified more than 40 proteins that associate with power speckles.
The first one was actually PSP C1 and but later they figured out that actually normal NSFQ are essential for the power cycle formation.
So we wanted to see if also normal NPS PC1 colocalized with G force it to our new foci.
Here is again perspective.

So we wanted to see if we can find them and we performed the same experiment, but this time we actually did Muna fluorescence for non MPs BC One an we found out that day two colocalized with the RNA foci.
We thought that was pretty interesting but there these are just sells right?
So we want to see if this is actually irrelevant in patient issue.
So we took a C9 or 72 positive cell cerebellum.
We chose the cerebellum because the foci are the most abundant there.
So we analyzed the postmortem brain tissue using fish, an immunohistochemistry an we found out that actually 4% of the RNA foci colocalized with FQ or non.
Quantification is shown here.
So we wanted to see if these foci could also associate with need one.
So are they part of the power speckles and to achieve this we also did the same experiment, this time with the double fish so we could pro fornite one and also for the RNA foci.
An actually.
About 14% of the foci colocalized with need one.
But that wasn't the only thing that we saw.
Also, there were some additional as if PQ stained subnuclear bodies, but there were negative for neat one an.
There were like 60% of those foci.
So we wanted we counted those foci because we wanted to see.
If.

There is an increase in the number of SFB khustain subnuclear bodies because of the foci, so we saw that actually the average number of these sub nuclear bodies increased from 2.34 mock transfected cells to 9.8 for the cells expressing due for city repeats.
And then we ask ourselves, could need one be actually replaced by G4C to repeat as a structural backbone for the para speckles?
To study that, we first establish a cell line Hexcel line with Nick need one knockdown.
So we did this using CRISPR CAS 9.
An then we validated this using real time PCR an as you can see there was very little residual need one present in the cells.
Then we performed similar experiment an we saw that actually there are still.
Full side that are also positive for SFP Q and then we saw that actually localization of the para special proteins is a neat one independent event.
Before I just show you the structure of the Paris Pechal, but here you can see that there are not only proteins in the Paris speckles, but also.
M RNA's that have inverted repeat Alo elements.
So this is also a signature of the fire speckles.
They're here.
In the middle.
So there is a human link RNA P1.
That has this aloe elements an it colocalizes with the power speckles.
So we wanted to see if also this RNA could colocalize with our perspective like structures.
And we found out that there is quite a high overlap between the signals, so it does actually Co. Localize this in the fire speckles.
So to conclude, G4C2 foci associated with the power spectral proteins normal SFB QMPCPS PC1.
This Association is independent of neutrons, so actually these repeats could act as a structural backbone for the para speckles.
And disperse beckerleg structures associate with the RNAs that can contain all or repeats.
And I'd like to thank first bodies.
Who's my mentor, Anne was leading this whole study and then Simona Mayan Sonya, who performed most of the experiments, an all of our collaborators.
Thank you.
